DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up on Panama Invasion, Other Market Reaction Muted
Eds: SUBS grafs 18-19, `I think ... South America, with two grafs to CORRECT attribution to Baker sted Byers
DOC.TEXT: The surprise attack by U.S. forces in Panama helped push the dollar higher today, but other financial markets reacted only mildly to the military intervention. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average was up about 4 points to the 2,700 level by noon EST. But in the broader market, declining stocks slightly outnumbered advances on the New York Stock Exchange. U.S. Treasury bond prices were unchanged to slightly higher in midday trading in New York. President Bush ordered troops into action following several days of tension triggered by the weekend shooting death of a U.S. military officer in Panama by defense forces controlled by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Currency dealers said the dollar rose sharply against other major currencies just after the military action became known early today. In Japan, the dollar closed at 144.23 yen, up 0.43 yen from Tuesday. It started the trading day at 143.92 yen and ranged between 143.90-144.25 yen. By midday in Europe, the dollar was up against all currencies except the yen while gold prices moved higher. The dollar remained firm in early New York dealings. In times of international tension, investors often look for safe havens and usually turn to the dollar and precious metals. Gabriele Schmitt, a trader with the Bank of New York, said she expected the dollar to be stable in the near term because of the uncertainty in Panama. ``There are still a lot of question marks,'' she said. ``Noriega still has a lot of support in his country ... I wouldn't rule him out entirely.'' But stock analysts said most investors did not view the unrest in Panama as a reason for making big changes in their strategies. ``The initial reaction is one of a non-event. It might have an impact if it becomes a prolonged situation,'' said Dennis E. Jarrett, a technical analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Co. Larry Wachtel, a vice president for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., agreed: ``We've been involved in limited (military) engagements before. This looks like a military engagement that will be over shortly.'' Wachtel said oil and defense stocks were getting a boost from the Panama invastion, however. The oil futures market initially rallied on the news amid concern that the closure of the Panama Canal might disrupt oil shipments, but prices fell back later in the trading session. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the leading grade of U.S. crude oil, was down around 5 cents at $21.21 per 42-gallon barrel by midday today. The January home heating oil contract, strengthened in recent days from a cold spell that hit parts of the nation, was up 0.54 cent to 76.85 cents a gallon, after rising nearly 2 cents earlier in the trading session. ``I think the reaction to the Panama closure was totally irrational,'' said Bob Baker, an energy analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``Our crude oil supplies simply won't be disrupted.'' Baker said that only a small percentage of crude shipped to the United States passes through the Panama Canal and the tankers that travel through the canal could be re-routed around South America.
